title: Gifts
text:
Gifts to the Translational Digestive Disease Research Center can help advance digestive disease research in five distinct ways:

Co-sponsoring a funded project. Our 40 faculty members have over 100 grants funded by foundations and the NIH through national competitions. However, many funding agencies have to cut proposed funding by 10-20% for financial reasons. Co-sponsoring a funded project at 20% can make a research project that has already won a national competition for funding more likely to succeed.
Co-funding pilot projects. These small grants of $50,000 are used to obtain important preliminary data to compete for larger national grants. Funding a pilot project often leads to larger future funding.
Endowing the Translational Digestive Disease Research Center. An endowment is the most stable form of long-term funding for each of the research cores and the programs of the TDDR Center. You can provide core funds that will fund digestive disease research in perpetuity.
Funding Collaborative Seed Grants. These grants help launch new collaborations between our Center Researchers, providing $25K for each grant to fund an early partnership, the experiments to develop preliminary data, and the application for larger funding.
Funding Bring Back a Technique Grants. These grants help fund travel to other centers to learn the latest techniques, and bring this knowledge back to teach our Center members. These grants provide $5K for each grant to fund travel and learning, to constantly keep our center on the cutting edge of science.

To find out more about gifts to the Translational Digestive Disease Research Center, contact:

title: Events
text:
Collaborative Seed Grants
Each year we evaluate applications for Collaborative Seed Grants (CSGs). Each member of the collaboration must put up some of their own (startup or discretionary) research dollars toward the project, for a total of $25K from the researchers, and apply for co-funding from the Center. The Center will provide a matching $25K in research funding to each of two collaborations each year. The goal of the CSGs is to launch new collaborations by providing dollars to obtain preliminary data for future, larger grants.

title: Events
text:
Bring Back a Technique Grants
Each year we evaluate applications for Bring Back a Technique Grants (BBATs). A faculty or staff member applies for a grant from the Center to travel to another institution to learn a new technique to bring back to our center, and to teach to others. The Center will provide up to $5K in travel funding to each of two BBAT proposals each year. The goal of the BBATs is to constantly reinvigorate our center with new techniques by providing dollars to travel and learn new approaches.

title: The Translational Digestive Disease Research (TDDR) Center at the University of Michigan
text:
The Programs
The TDDR Center includes two programs:

The Enrichment Program
This program is responsible for several activities that enrich the scientific environment for digestive disease research at the University of Michigan, including the fortnightly in-person gatherings on Wednesday afternoons, Bring Back a Technique (BBAT) mini-sabbaticals, Collaboration Seed Grants (CSG), and our annual Research Retreat.
The Pilot & Feasibility Program
This program is responsible for advertising, soliticing, and evaluating applications for pilot and feasibility grants of up to $50,000 to fund research leading to preliminary data toward a larger NIH-funded grant.
